text: death for the WDM marder of his wife in the Rhondda Valley. This sentence Ha* now been commuted to penal servitude Mr life. A man named Bradford was charged at Kid- derminster on Sunday with attempting to murder Ids father. Going home intoxicated he UiittDjr attacked the old man With a hatchet, inflicting sn<Jh injuries that it is feared the man cannot recover. . On Tuesday Jas. Jones, draper, Birmingham, vMU committed for trial charged with fraudulent bank- ruptcy. He failed for 15,000?., with brft trifling assets ; and it is alleged that be bad previously sold under heavy discounts large quantities of goods bought in Manchester and Bradford. At Liverpool on Tuesday James McDermott was charged before Mr. Raffles with conspiring to murder subjects of her Majesty. The prisoner was arrested on board the steamer City of Montreal On its arrival from New York. Evidence was pradnced con- necting him with Dal ton and others of the prisoners who are now undergoing penal servitude for life, and the prisoner was again remanded. At Pensanee en Monday, Frederick Chaplain, a captain in the Salvation Amy, was fined 10*. and costs for obstructing a thoroughfare by holding a service in one of the principal streets in the borough. He re- fused to pay a fine, and was committed to gaol for 14 days. As be was being taken to the railway station a crowd of sympathisers followed, ami bustled and hissed the police. Private Alex. Montgomery, of the 9th Lanark Rifle Volunteers, has been committed for trial on a charge of fraudulently altering hfs scoring dmriS fct the meeting of the Midlothian Rifle Association, whereby he was declared winner of the Caledonian Shield, the Standard gold cross, and 26i. The prisoner is accused of having entered larger totals at the three ranges than he actually scored, and then forged the register-keeper's initials to complete the fraud. At Leicester on Monday, Frederick Smith and Joseph Hodges, butchers, were charged with having a diseased carcase of a cow, intended for human food, in their possession. The Town Cleric prosecuted. It ap- peared that defendants purchased a cOw for 9i., and had it dressed for human food, Smith Stating that they had intended to send it to London the day it was seized. The meat was in a shocking state. Hodges was dis- charged, but tbe Magistrates held tint the ease against Smith was so serious that they must send him to prison for two months. " Madame Rachel " Sausages.—On Tuesday David Oraham, of Messrs. Duncan and David Oraham, wholesale butchers, New City-road, Glasgow, was fined Hi. or 40 days' imprisonment for selling sausages Unfit for human food. The meat was seasoned Or freshened in colour With sulphate Of lime, a process known in the trade as " Madame Rachel." Beery. Water.—At seven o'clock on Friday morning, on tbe farm of Mr. Geo. Melsome, Beacon-hill, near Amesbury, in Wilts, commenced a singular match for slasting all day in broiling hot weather, during which the corn in tbe district around was being rapidly cut down. The contest, which was under the auspices of the Church of England Temperance Society, was the re- sult of a bet at a public meeting at Salisbury, and was between Mr. Terrell, a Wiltshire farmer, who challenged his opponent first, and Mr. Abbey, an Oxfordshire farmer and lecturer for the society. The issue was who would do the most work in the harvest field, the former drink- ing beer and tbe latter water only. Fifteen acres to each " pitcher " were allowed. The result was that beer won by above an acre. Mt. Terrell fro* the first held a very considerable lead, and at four o'clock the ground cleared by Him was 15a. 3r. 16p. and by Mr. Abbey 14a. 3r. AUeged Murder at Ipswich.—At Ipswich police-court on Monday Thcmiat Lyons Day, an ex- soldier from tbe Coldstream Guards, was committed for trial on charges of murdering Lilian Alice Lyons Meek and maliciously wounding William Woodgate. The deceased girl was tbe illegitimate child of the prisoner, but ber mother, having married Woodgate, she lived with him. The prisoner went to the house to see the child, and while nursing it cot its throat with a pocket knife, and on Woodgate interfering a scuffle ensued, in which he was wounded in the head so severely that be has been a fortnight in the hospital. Fresh evidence was given of the prisoner having been seen to sharpen his knife early on the day of the murder. It aIM came ont for the first time that the prisoner told a sergeant of police on the night of the muider that be bad got hie knife out to cut some hard tobacco, and that the child slipping off his knee became accidentally wounded, upon which Woodgate and his wife rushed at him The cross- examination was with a view to support this theory. The Dimttery of Dead Bodies at Bermotulsey. —Soon after Mr. Slade had taken his seat on the bench at the Southwark police-court On the 23d dMective- seTgeant Piekels, of tbe M division, informed hi# Worship that several persons had applied at the Beimoodsey police-station relative to 11 dead infants discovered at an undertaker's premises at 79, Long lane, Betmondsey. These persons appeared to be very poor, bat stated that they had paid the undertaker sums of money to the extent of se. each, on tbe promise that the bodies should be buried. Tbe children appeared to have been stillborn, and the police procured certificates of the death in each case. They a 8 seemed to be very indignant at the con- duct of the undertaker, and he was instructed to apply to his Worship as to whether some criminal proceedings could not be taken against the undertaker.—Mr. Slade asked If the coroner had instituted an inquiry relative to (he discovery of the bodies.—Sergeant Pickels replied that he understood an inquest would be held that day. The persons who applied to tbe police were in' court, mid they thought that the undertaker should be apprehends! for obtaining money from them by fraud and false pre- tences.—Mr. Slade observed that there was no fraud or false pretence, as the undertaker had made no Spec Hie contract as to the burial. The parties, however, might proceed in the County Court if they thought proper. He however thought that the sanitary authorities in tfte district should take the matter up.—Sergeant Piekels said that they had been applied to, but they declined to interfere at present.—Mr. Slade toM him that he could not interfere, as there was nothing before him.—Mr W. J. Payne held an inquiry at tbe coroner's eourt, High- street, Borough, upon the 11 bodies. The coroner decided to take two of the cases where the bodies bad already been identified. Ellen Jadraon, of 11, Vletoria- ptaee, CoHyer'a-rents, deposed to tbe birth of a stillborn child on August 3. Her husband arranged with Mr. Camden to buty it for 51. He said it was to be buried at Plaistow on the following Wednesday. He took it a Way in a small box. It was dressed at that time. The coroner's officer said tbe children bad all been stripped it the mortuary and thrown naked into one box. Tbe witness said she could not recognise any ehSd as hers, but She would know the nightdress again. Henry Smith, an undertaker, deposed to tbe last witness's baby being fetched away on Bank-holiday to the shop. Detective- sergeant Pickets deposed to finding the bodies in a sheH on the premises at 72, Long-lane. They were aD pinned up in cloths The jury returned a verdict of " found dead." The Murder near Croydon.—Mr. Morrison, the coroner for the Croydon division of Surrey, held an inquiry on the 23d, at New Thornton Heath, as to the death of Thomas Cole, aged 3 years and 8 months, who died from the effects of injuries received at the hands of his father, James Cole, who is in custody on the capital chaise. —The first witness caned was Richard Cole, who said he resided with his father (the accused) at 12, Pridham-road West, New Thornton Heath.. His father was a brickmaker and labourer. On the evening in question his father swore he would take his mother's Hfe. There was only some bread in the house, and his fkther threatened to take her life for keeping him without better food. About 8 o'clock his mother went home and hb father again threatened her. She after- wards got tip And dressed herself and went to the gate. While she was standing there the next door neighbour called her. When tfhe came back she said to her husband, "1 can't sleep a minute for your slang." It was a woman named Poster who called her. She said, " Mm. Cole, I want to speak to you," and his mother went and spoke to her at the gate. All of a sudden His mother ran back to her own house, at the gate of which witness waa standing. When his mother opened the door Witness Aw his father holding the deceased up by the feet and k&ockfng his head on tbe floor. He then threw the child over his shoulder and dropped it on the floor. His mother seized his father by the collar just as he was about to take up his little sister. When his mother first rushed in she saw what her husband was about to do with Tommy, and screamed out " Murder f and " Oh! he's miing my child." After that his mother seized the deceased and placed him on the bed.— Robert Gilbert, of 1, Pridham-road West, deposed that at he was going home on Sunday night the 19th he heard cries of "Murder!" He rushed to Cole's house and saw the accused dash tbe deceased against tbe wall of the front room. Witness pulled him out of the house and handed him over to a constable.—Harriett Harding, a married woman, living at 11, Pridham-road West, Mid that on the night in question she was standing at her door, when die heard Cole using filthy language towards Us wife. By the Coroner: Cole Was of tatompentte habits. When he was sober he would stay indoor* all the week and not search for work. She did not tiwnk the accused had had anything to drink on Sunday. She knew he had been in prison many times, and that be was a very desperate man. On one occasion his trite jumped out of a first-floor window to assaps from mm While he was chasing her with a knife.—Tbe jury returned a verdict of "wilful murder" against James Cole. Hie lease eendataed pruritics ijmisst sub-letting and otha* tUn*, but the chief objection was to the rani. Of coarse this did not ge> ylnJtadtagj^ntotorseO: --\. , .. • v .. v. ✓V-*--. * • QCIM fit 4A AMM wow ■ow wt wuupuwoj vv bbvuvi wan win* menced on Saturday at Braff, comity limerick. Dr. Win. P. Coaollv and Thomas his brother were charged with attempting to cause poison to 1m administered to Thomas Carrofl ana to his sister. The evidence of the principal witness. Michael Deenan, showed that under the fnlhience ot Mm BOctor and his brother he had frequently attempted to waylay and shoot Carroll with a revolver, and, thta failing, had been asked to poison bottt the latter and his sister. When he refused to do this the prisoners seized him, and tried to force him to drink some whiskey which h® belie Ted to have been poisoned. They could not do tM», however, and let him go, and then he gave informa- tion to the police as to what he knew. fie prisoners wore remanded without bail. The Assanxiiuitwn of Carey.—Messrs. Donald Carrie and Co.'s steamer Norham Castle arrived in Plymouth Sound on Sunday evening, and brings the con- tinuation of the evidence given before the Natal Magis- trates, when O'Donnell was charged with the murder of James Carey.—Mrs. Carey, who looked greatly distressed, said that she was the wife of the deceased James Carey, and came out in the Kinfanns Castle with her husband and seven children. She knew the prisoner O'Donnell, who came from London in the same mat. They used to speak to each other. O'Donnell landed in Cape Town with them. Her husband was the man who gave tho evidence in the Irish trials. She left London by herself, and her husband met her at Dartmouth. She had never seen O'Donnell before, and her husband and O'Donnell never talked together aliout the trials. They were steer- age passengers, and O'Donnell was second class. Worm- in gt on, a detective in Dublin, put the name " Power " on their boxes to avoid detection. She did not know who paid their passage money. Witness went on to say that she recollected Sunday, July 29, when she sawher husband running toward her, saying, " Maggie, I am shot, and O'Donnell shot me." Witness asked prisoner who shot him, and prisoner replied, " I shot him; I was sent to do it." Prisoner said, "Your name is not Power; it is Carey." Mrs. O'Donnell said to her husband, " You are no Informer, O'Donnell." Witness did not shake hands with O'Donnell. The prisoner was sitting on the seat. O'Donnell during the day had asked witness, previous to the murder, where her husband was, when she replied, "On deck," when prisoner said, " Call him down." Witness did so, and the prisoner and deceased had some beer together. O'Donnell and her husband used to play dice on deck. The passage out took 21 days, and during that time O'Donnell and her husband were on the best OT terms. Prisoner bad told her that he had left the ship in Cape Town. O'Donnell was jealous of Carey, as ht had been too attentive to his wife on the Sunday after- noon. On Sunday she left deceased ami O'Donnell together. Deceased was standing and O'Donnell and hit wife were sitting on the settee together. She did not see the first shot Sred, but heard the third. She did not heai any strong words pass between them, and never heard hei husband threaten to shoot O'Donnell. Afterwards ah* fainted and was put into a cabin. Slie had no money and did not know what she would do. She supposed her hus- band would have looked for employment. Mrs. Carey, who had conducts 1 herself in a most becoming manner, and for whom evident sympathy was manifested in court, having signed her depositions, left the court.—llan-y tireenhough said he was a second-class passenger on board the Melrose for Natal. On the Sunday afternoon he was on deck between 1 and half-past and heard O'Donnell say, "He shall not leave the ship." He was not certain whether he said "he " or " she." The deceased and th« prisoner were on the be>t of terms.—Thomas Francis Carey, an intelligent-looking lad, said : I am 15 years of age. When my father was shot I was on the stairs lead- ing to the second-class saloon. I saw my father standing near one of the cabins on the starboard side. He was smiling and talking with O'Donnell. I saw Mr. O'Donneil draw a revolver from his inside pocket and tire one shoi at my father. The bullet struck him in the neck. I can- not say whether the prisoner stood up, but I saw him fir* a second shot. Just at this moment my mother ran out. My father ran into my mother's arms and cried out, " Maggie, Maggie, I am shot. M'Donald has shot me.' We used to call O'Doiwell M'Donald ou board ship. Mj mother was holding my father when the third shot was fired. I was standing near the berths at the time. I took from my father's pocket a cheque for 1001. It was drawn on the South African Bank at Natal. I found the cheque this morning. I gave the cheque to my mother this morning. She knew nothing of it until then. My mothei can neither read nor write. Mr. Dallmont, chief detectivc in Dublin, gave the cheque to my father.—The prisonei pleaded not guilty, and said that be acted in self-defence, as Carey pulled a revolver out of his right hand pocket. —The prisoner was then taken from the dock, and after a short interview with his agent was conveyed to the North-end gaol.—O'Donnell arrived at Capetown on Sun- day morning in the Athenian. He was to leave on Tuesday evening. His friends are supplying him with everything he wants to eat and drink.—Mrs. Carey will leave with the other witnesses in a few days. She will, it is believed, give important evidence hitherto withheld from fear of the consequences to .her late husband.—At a meeting ol the Irish-Americans held at Nashville on Monday a large sum of money was collected for the defence of O'Donnell.

TOPICS OF THE DAY. THE CITIZEN, FRIDAY, AUGUST 31, 1883 later telegrams received from Java show that the : recent volcanic errnption was terribly destructive. The native huts all along the beach have been washed away. Three towns, Anjer, Tuiringen, and Telok* betong, have been destroyed. Lighthouses in the Sunda Straits have disappeared. " Where once the* mound of Kramatau stood, the sea now plays." Anjer was completely washed away by the tidal wave which followed the eruption *of Krakatoa, and there has been great loss of life both here and among the Europeans and natives in North Bantam* The eruptions which have occurred in the Sund» straits have made navigation dangerous, for islands have disappeared and new ones arisen. The charts are therefore no longer to be relied upon, an& tbe Government have already commenced taking measures to obtain fresh soundings. In consequence of the eruptions in the Straits of Sunda, the Board of* Trade has requested the Foreign Office, Colonial Office, and India Office to telegraph to the Governors andY Consuls at different ports, to warn all vessels which may be approaching the Straits of Sunda. The total! extent of the disaster is not known and much alarm is naturally created throughout Holland, the greatest- anxiety being felt by those who have friends of' relations;iiving in the places affected. mm* Java is making good its right to contest with Japatt the grim title of the " Lid of Hell." The world which* lately stood aghast at the catastrophe in Isobia is now confronted with a far more terrible disaster in th© Straits of Sunda. It may yet be some weeks at least before a detailed description of this latest eruption reaches this country, so a Bhort history of previous eruptions may not be without interest. Java, with it* sixteen active and innumerable quiescent volcanoes is used to eruptions. In 1772, a volcano in the south-west of the island, threw out such an immense quantity "of scorifo and ashes in a single night, that an; area having a radius of seven miles waff- covered with a layer 50 feet thick. Forty native villages were buried beneath it, and 3,000 persons are supposed to have perished in this one nighw A still>ore terribly destructive eruption was that on Mount [Galunggong, a few miles east of the former, which occurred in October, 1822. Without warning a dense mass arosejfrom the old volcano and spread with such rapidity that in a few moments the whole landscape was shrouded in the darkness of night A deluge of hot water and mnd shot up from the crater and poured down tbe mountain sides, sweeping away trees and beasts and human bodies in its seething mass- Nearly everything was destroyed for a radius of nearly twenty miles round. A second eruption four day* after completed the catastrophe. This was accompanied by an earthquake ; the summit of the mountain was broken down ; one side, covered with forest, became a semi-circular gulf ; new hills and valleys are said to have been formed, and rivers had their courses changed. As many as 114 villages were destroyed on this occasion, and 4,000 people killed. The news of the day from Berlin ia that Prince Bismarck and Count Kalnoky, the Foreign Minister* of Germany and Austria, have met at Salzburffv Accompanied by his wife and his eldest exm, Count Herbert, Prince Bismarck left Kissingen on Thursday, and arrived tbis ; afternoon at Salzburg, where he wa» joined, or two later, by Count Kalnoky. It waff at Salzburg, in 1865, a few weeks before the signature of the Convention of Gastein, that Herr yon Bismarck told the Bavarian Minister, Herr yon der Pfordten, that a war between Prussia and Austria was inevitable. "One encounter, one decisive battle," he said, "and Prussia will have itinher power todictate conditions." Eighteen years have passed since then ; and now the repre* sentatives of Germany and Austria meet to confer or* the best means of preserving to Europe the blessing of peace. For it cannot be doubted, says the Timer correspondent, that this was the main object of their interview. It is admitted on all hands that the meeting of tbe two statesmen is a noteworthy political event- Monarchs may meet from motives of neighbourly courtesy and personal friendship; but when Foreign Ministers travel long distances to converse with each other, their reasons for doing so must be more' important and more interesting. Tbe warning given to France by the semi-official North German Gazette was emphasised yesterday by the same paper, which, as is well known, is generally accepted as the organ of Prince Bismarck. An articl* which appeared yesterday stated that the article against France which caused so mnch sensation in Europe was not intended as a menace, but as a warning* It professes itself to believe that the thanks of all friends of peace, even in France, are due to it for having given a timely warning of the consequence* which would result from the systematic agitation carried on in France with the object of stirring up hate* against Germany, and in favour of war with tbat country. Will France submit to the warning thu* imperatively given? Fuller accounts have now been received of the treaty of peace concluded between the French and Annamese* authorities at Hue, and it is evident that the French have not failed to secure the fruits of their recent success, such as it was. The net result of tbe arrangement is that France, by virtue of its stipula' tions, and so far as they may be held valid by Chinay becomes protector—in other words lord paramount; over all the territory claimed as his by the ruler at Annam. In order to secure the fruits of her military and diplomatic exertions, the Rupublio has acquired the right to hold permanently the forts at the mouth of the Hue River, together with posts which command the roads from Annam to Cochin-China. This latter province has been increased by the cession of " Bit* Thuan" on its northern border, and a line of telegraph is to be carried from Saigon to Hanoi, presumably overland. A resident, M. Champeanx, is to take up his quarters in Hue, and enjoy the right of private audienc* with the so-called Sovereign. Moreover, the* whole Customs administration—a most significant provision—falls into French hands, while the " system v governing its conduct will be settled later by » special envoy. Thus the control over the kingdom i* complete. Nor is that specifically established, at least on paper, in the Tonquin province less absolute. There* the French may erect, on the Red River, possibly else- where, such fortifications as they please. In every town where it may be thought worth while, a Resident will be stationed, and it is remarkable that certain towns to the south-west—that is, over towards the Sian» frontier — are included by name. The official* nominated, it is laid down, may be accompanied by " French forces to the extent judged necessary by th* French Government." Tbe end and object with whid» France is credited in these transactions is the reduc- tion of Siam, so that the whole of what is called Indo- China—except British Burmah—may become a French possession. The application by the Chairman of the Jordan Valley Canal Company to her Majesty's Government for the loan of £8,000,000, to be a first charge on their undertaking, is perhaps one of the coolest propcsad* *Ver placed before any Government. The total **pital of the company, they say, will be 20,000,0C0 ■terling, and the company is willing to allow the *oan to be a first charge on the undertaking, and will Provide a sinking fund for its redemption within a Period of fifty years. If tbat is unobtainable they will J* much obliged if the Government will guarantee interest at 3£ per cent, upon the whole or any portion °* the company's capital of £20,000,000. At tbe present problematical in tbe highest degree whether *°ere is any possibility of opening a navigable highway the Mediterranean Sea and the Jordan Valley. *be proposal is for communicating canals, one com- mencing at Haifa, in the Bay of Acre, to connect the Mediterranean with the northern end of the Jordan •alley, and the other to run along the Waddy-Arabah, *° loin the Dead Sea with tbe Gulf of Akabah. 111- **tured people oppose this brilliant scheme by the *cry ugliest and hardest facts. Sir Charles W. Wilson, authority none can dispute, vouches for the fact 'bat the watershed in the " Valley of Akaba," between *be Dead and the Red Sea, through which the canal is *° is 781 feet above the level of tbe latter, and 2,040 feet above that of the former. And a writer in c September number of Blackwood's Magazine the cost of the two canals, from the Gulf of to the Jordan Valley, and from the Dead Sea to *be South, at £222,705,000 or 2£ millions sterling per *tile 1 The Sultan of Turkey too, is understood *° bave expressed an opinion tbat he is by 110 means in favour of the Jordan valley canal. That Prime Minister does not look kindly upon the Proposal is manifest from his reply to the Executive when he acquainted tbat body that he had •eferred the question to the Foreign Secretary, to whose department Mr. Gladstone considered the subject Matter seemed to belong. The idea of creating a Waterway from Acre Bay, on tbe Mediterranean, to •*-kabah, on tbe Red Sea, taking advantage of tbe deep depressions through which the Jordan flows, is, we '"ay remark, no new suggestion. Twenty or more 'ears ago it was discussed, and at various times since, the feasibility of this great ditch has been debated in * bap-hazard kind of way. Its revival as a British *°b*me—for on its initiation it was, like the Suez G*nal, a French notion —is of course due to the diffi- culties which have arisen in connection with M. de **88eps' great work, and the exclusive right which he *Uims of cutting waterways through the isthmus.

THE VOLCANIC DISTURBANCES IN JAVA. Sixteen volcanoes have appeared between the site where Krakatoa stood and Sibisie Island. The Soen- gepan volcano has split into five. A portion of tbe presidency of Bantam is an ash desert. The cattle are without food, and tbe population are in despair. Dead bodies are now being recovered in tbe district of Tanara ; 704 bave already been buried at Kramat, and 300 in the district of Serang Fort.

VOLCANIC ERUPTIONS IN JAVA. IMMENSE DESTRUCTION. Batavia, Ansf. 27. Terrific detonations from tha volcanic island at Krakatoa were heard last night, and were audible as far as Soerakarta, showers of ashes falling as far as Cheribon. The flashes from the volcano are plainly visible Jfrom here. Serang is now in total darkness. Stones have fallen at that place. Eatavia is also nearly in darkness, all the gas lights being extinguished during the night. It is impossible to communicate with Anjer, and it is feared that some calamity has happened there. Several bridges between Anjer and Serang have been destroyed, and a village near the former place has been washed away, the rivers having overflowed through the rush of the sea inland.

A GREAT TIDAL WAVE. Batavia, Aug. 23. The eruption of the Krakatoa volcano, which com- menced on the 26tb, is of a formidable character. North Bantam is suffering heavily from a dense con- tinuous shower of ashes, mud, and pumice stone, which almost ruined tha crops and orchards, besides damming the roads and bridges. A tidal wave has swept away tho European quarter of Anjer and the Chinese camp at Merak. Telegraphic communication is now inter- rupted between Bantam and this city. Batavia was in darkness for several hours yesterday, owing to the thick rain of ashes proceeding from the volcano. Tho lower quarters of the city have been swamped by a tidal wave, but the godowns and entrepots are not damaged.

THE EVENING POST. Friday, August 31, 1883. It is understood that the War Office has now tinder consideration a proposal for extending and Reorganising the defences of the port of Liverpool, »nd that an important decision on the subjsct may be come to at au early date. So many fictions (writes a correspondent) have found publication in connection with Sir Stafford Northcote's health, that it may be as well to men- tion his almost complete recovery from tho ex- haustion consequent upon his prolonged parlia- mentary labours. " A friend of the family," the writer add 3, " assures me that the distinguished -statesman is iv far better health than he was a couple of months back." Nottingham horticulturists are not likely to be behindhand in preparing for the International Horticultural Exhibition, which, it appears, is to take place in London next year. The subject of Such an exhibition was much discussed so long ago as 1878 and 1879, but nothing has yet been done to carry out the suggestion. It is clear, with the help ot our colonial dependencies, that the whole of the space now occupied by the Fisheries Exhibition might be quite filled, and be made at least as in- teresting and instructive to the general public as the present exhibition. The whole of the build- ings might remain almost as they are, eacli country refilling the space with objectß suitable, «nd in keeping with the next year's show, which, we should say, if at all carefully managed, can scarcely fail of success. At Genoa the importance of the proper nursing and treatment of infants is so highly regarded that the municipal authorities have determined to gratis to all those who present themselves at the offices to register the birth of a child a small tract or pamphlet containing brief directions for "the healthy rearing of the now-born. The idea is a good one, and it is to be hoped the Genoese population may be improved by its means, but we can scarcely recommend it for adoption in this country. As regards pamphlets and tracts Englishmen are divided into two classes, those who write and those who destroy them, It is a I painful fact that people can with difficulty be got to read what is good for them, and if they know it is presented from a philanthropic motive their "prejudice is the more confirmed. Let us hope tho * Oenoese aro more sensible in this respect. Householders will not be very pleased to learn that their implacable foes, the fraternity of thieves, have discovered a new method, and a very cruel one, for the pursuit of their nefarious ends. It is Ho less than the setting of houses on fire in order to utilise the confusion consequent thereon to rob either the houses so ignited, or, more probably, others in the neighbourhood. Early yesterday morning two houses in the neigh- bourhood of Prince's Park, Liverpool, were found to be on fire, and it was also evident that the fire was not the result of accident, In each case a window had been broken and burning matches •scattered inside the room, igniting curtains and other articles. Some days ago it appears there was a very similar occurrence in Birkenhead ; but in that case it wa3 thought that some personal malice might explain the outrage. In the Prince's Park affair no such supposition is feasible, and the conclusion come to is that the fires were caused by evil disposed persons, to divert the attention of the police from their own proceedings. Fortu- nately, the amount of damage sustained was not very great, and the local authorities will now be on guard against the commission of similar offences. As, however, there is no reason to suppose that the new crime will be confined to Liverpool, a hint of warning to the public and the police in our own district may not be without use. Some idea may be formed of the awful nature of the catastrophe which has visited the north- west coast of Java from the later details now to hand. The district around the volcano of Krakatoa has been converted into an ashy desert, in which cattle seek for pasturage in vain, and the inhabitants find all means of support suddenly denied them. So terrible has been the power of the volcanic forces that the mountain itself has been destroyed, only, however, to give origin to sixteen new volcanoes. Another crater we read of as having been split into five parts, and on the whole the work of destruction could scarcely be more complete. As to the loss of life this is on a scale equal to the other proportions of the catas- trophe. The thousand bodies already recovered from the ruins andjnterred can, it is to b'j feared, only be regarded as'" the first fruits of the huge harvest of death reaped by tho demoniac energy of the great volcano. Englishmen have little interest in Java or its people, but a disaster of this magnitude will not fail to appeal tn our national sympathy, and possibly to our generosity as well. Concerning the scientific aspect of the catastrophe, it is, perhaps, too early to speak definitely, but ite occurrence so soon after the Ischia earthquake lends considerable support to the theory that these subterranean forces are m some way connected, and it is also by no means impossible that the destructive tidal wave which has just visited the Atlantic coast of North America may owe its origin to another develop- ment of the same hidden agency, The latest telegrams from the East show that the Treaty which has been concluded between France and Annam i 3 of a somewhat sweeping character. The former Power practically assumes a suzerainty over the Annamese kingdom, and this, too, in distinct defiance as it were of the submis- sion claimed by China of the King of Annam. Such arrangements are not always of a happy kind, as witness the British suzerainty over the Trans- vaal, and it will remain to be seen whether China will without a struggle surrender a right upon which she evidently set 3 considerable value. The gain of France is, however, of by no means a merely sentimental nature. To securo the fruits of her military and diplomatic exertions, the Republic has acquired the right to hold permanently the forts at the mouth of the Hue River, together with posts which command the roads from Annam to Cochin-China. This latter province has been increased by the cession of Bin Thuan on its northern border, and a line of telegraph is to bo carried from Saigon to Hanoi, presumably overland. A Resident, M. Champeaux, is to take up his quarters in Hue, and enjoy tho right of private audience with the nominal Sovereign. Moreover, it is most significant that the whole Customs administration falls into French hands, while the "system" governing its conduct will be settled later by a special envoy. In short, the control of France over this Eastern kingdom appears to be of an absolute nature, and apparently the same provisions are to apply to the province of Tonquin. The treaty gives the French authorities a right to erect fortifications on the Red River, at their own discretion, and probably elsewhere in the province also. All suspicious movements of the population will be most jealously watched, for which purpose a Resident is to be stationed in each of the principal towns, including certain places towards the Siamese frontier, which are specially mentioned, an indication of the idea in the minds of those who framed the treaty that this frontier might, in future, serve as a useful base for further conquests for the glory and advantage of France. Indeed it is impossible to accept any other view of the case when we remember that the persons nominated to these offices are to be accompanied by " French forces to the extent judged necessary by the French Government." In short, it would seem that the Republican negotiators have acquired, potentially, all the territory between the sea and the Siamese and Chinese frontiers, : and such a movement can only be interpreted as signifying a desire on the part of the French for the possession of a second India. After the con- quest of the Siamese Empire the whole peninsula ' of Further India, with tho exception of British Burmah, would practically be at the mercy of the French, and the new ambition of our neigh- ' bours would be gratified, although at a cost which they hardly at present reckon on. They have not yet subdued what they are } pleased to term the " rebellion" in Ton- L quin, but their animosity is so strong against the natives who resist their will in this quarter that one of the chief Paris newspapers actually recommends the treating of these patriots as 4 "malefactors." As we have before remarked, [ however, China will almost certainly have to be reckoned with it if the French "tideof conquest " is to proceed. The Chinese Court seems to have established very good terms with Germany, and in the immediate neighbourhood of her ' own territory China could with ease pour down on the French such a mass of well-armed ' and fairly-trained men as would be very calculated to give pause to their small expedition. ' Some of the French newspapers seem to observe ' the danger threatening in this quarter. "Wo have . succeeded in Hue'," remarks the Parlement, "but F . we must not think of recommencing the Chinese 1 expeditions of 1860. Neither do we think our Government will be reduced to try it. If, as 5 seems not doubtful, China has at least indirectly encouraged the Black Flags, it is owing to our 1 weakness and hesitation. China fancied the ' least check would upset our frail colonial edifice. * Now that she knows better, there will be 1 no alternative but frank friendship or open war. France greatly prefers the first solution, and the interests of China should dictate to her an * analogous policy." This is sound policy, although I couched in rather patronising terms, and, if the 5 French Government bo wise, it will rest content k with its present victory without too eagerly rush- l ing into new and more dubious undertakings.

VOLCANIC ERUPTIONS AND TIDAL WAVES Every 1 nglishman who has journeyed to the far East (says the Tim ') is familiar with An.er Point, on tho north-west coast of Java, as one of the welcome places of call where a stock of fresh vegetables'aod fruit can bo laid in. Opposite this. In Sunda Strait, lies tha volcanic island of Krakatoa, the eruption of which has lad to what is feared may bo a swooping disast r. Serang and Batavia, as announced, wera in darkness on the 27th, while the ashes and stones discharged from the volcano had travelled as far as Cheribon, some 253 miles distant, This was followed by a "tidal wave" which choked up the rivers, oversowed tho land, and swept away the European quarter at Anjer and tho Chinese camp at Merak. Java, with its 16 activc, and innumerable quiescent volcanoes, is mad to eruptions, some of which have even boen mora destructive than tho Ischia earthquake. This volcano of Krakatoa has been in a state of unusual activity for some weeks, Somo of tha Java volcanoes rise to ■ height of 12,090: t In 17 T2 the volcano of Papandayang, in tho south-west part of the Island, threw out such an immense quantity of scori >- and ashes In a single night that an area of seven miles was covered with a layer -0 feet thick. Eorty native villages were buried and OJO persons are supposed to have perished in this one night. Still more terrible destructive was.the eruption of Mount Galunggong, a few miles east of the former, on October 8, 18-li. About mid-day, a dark, dense mass rose from tha old volcano and spread itself out with such ap- palling rapidity that in a few moments the whole landscape was shrouded in the darkness oi night Bright flashes occasionally pierced the darkness, a deluge of hot water and mud shot up from the crater and poured down tha mountain sides, sweeping away trees and beasts and human' bodies. Nearly everything was destroyed for 20 miles round. A second eruption four days after completed the catastrophe. This was accom- panied iby an earthquake; the summit of the mountain was broken down; and new bills and valleys were formed, and rivers had their courses changed. As many as 114 villages wero destroyed, and 4000 people killed. In it is estimated that Mount Gu .tuo flung forth ashes and Gand to the extent of 2j,000,000 tons; in ISG7 an earthquake caused the death of 1000 people in the town of Jokgokarta alone ; in 1572 one of the most active volcanoes, Merapi, brought death to many of the dwellers around. Earth n'.aUes destructive to life are of frequent occurrcnco; tha most celebrated is that of January 5, IG'j9, when 203 shocks wero felt, and many houses in Batavia destroyed. Mud volca- noes, gas fountains, and hot springs are common ovar the islnnd. There seems little doubt that the so-called " tidal wave " which has swept over ; the coast of Java is intimately connected with the volcanic activity of the mountain in the bay. : This kind of wava is of ft totally different I character and origin from the last destructive wave that visited that quarter of the world, the 1 cyclone wave of Bengal, on October 31, 1870, which, sweeping up the Bay of Bengal to the low-lying oountry around the mouth of the i Oanges, covered an area of TOOO square miles, and in ft few minutes destroyed 213,000 lives. The last great "tidal wave" was on June 10, 1H77, when an enormous wava spread itself from tho Sandwich Islands to the Peruvian coast, and even made itself felt in Australia and New '/ ea- land. This wave was certainly coincident with ft i violent eruption of Mount Kilanoa, in Hawaii, and frequent earthquake shooks and ernp- ! tions on the west coast of South America, I Both in the Sandwich Islands and in Peru I the wave repeatedly charged over the land, carrying ships far inland and destroying every- I thing that cpme In its way. Curiously enough, i on the same date a very marked shook of earth- i quake was felt at Comrio, Perthshire, the most ' frequent centre of seismic activity in this country. Kut this earthquake wave was not nearly so de- structive to life as that which in list 8 destroyed i the towns of Arica and Arequipa, in Peru, when i 00,000 lives were lost I The National League.— Mr I'arnell pre- sided at a meeting of the < rganising Committeo or the Irish National Lenguo hold yesterday in ; i übiin. Mr Davitt also attended. The sum of f'Oll was acknowledged since last meoting, and ' £'5'' f i was voted for tho relief of evicted tenants >in diti'orent parts of the cotintr /. It is proposed to bold a sorios of great popular demonstrations ; throughout the provinces during tha next fort- jniebt,

THE VOLCANIC ERUPTION IN JAVA. SPECIAL EDITION "Tilcobaph" Onioi, 7.50 p. if, BURIAL OF THE DEAD. Bat a via, August 29, 6.30 p.m. Sixteen volcanoes have appeared betweeu tha site where Krakatoa stood and Sibisie Island. The Soengepan volcano has split into five. A portion of the Residency of Bantam is an ashy desert. The cattle are without food, and the population in despair. August 30, 4 p.m. Dead bodies are now being recovered. In th 3 district of Tanara 704 have already been buried, in the coast village of Kramat 300, mostly Chinese, and iu the district of Serang 40. The Hague, August 30. An official despatch of to day's data, received from the Governor of the Dutch East Indies, announces that the eruption ot Krakatoa on the 26th inst. destroyed a great part of Northern Bantam, and deprived the inhabitants of their means of subsistence. The population were flying from the country in despair. On the 27th August a tidal wave from 12 to 30 metres in height swept the coast of Merak as far as Turin gin. The towns of Anjer, Merak, and Tuiringin were overwhelmed, together with all the Govern- ment buildings; and the lighthouses at Vierde- punt, in Java, and Vlakkehock, in Sumatra, were likewise destroyed. Five European and several native functionaries at Anjer and Tuiringin have perished, The aspect of the Straits of Sunda haa undergone a complete transformation. The island of Krakatoa has disappeared. Sixteen volcanic craters are visible between Krakatoa and Sibesie. The full extent of the disaster has not yet been ascertained. THE " FIRST OF SEPTEMBER." The prospects of sport to-morrow in the Dur- ham district for partridge shooting are better than they have been for a few seasons past. I NEW RAILWAY. Sir Daniel Gooch, M.P., turned to-day the fir* sod of the new railway to connect Oldbury, Worcestershire, with the main line of the Great Western Railway, of which he is chairman. THE RECENT COURT MARTIAL ON A PRIVATE SOLDIER. Private Kimber.of the 4th Hussars, charged with having accused his captain of having connived at his beiDg thrown into the Thames by his com- rades, has been sentenced to four months' im- prisonment. THE COATBRIDGE RIOTS, At Aiidiie, to day, James Simpson was found guilty of assaulting a constable on the 18th inst , p.car Coatbridge. It appeared that whilst the Orangemen and Catholics were fighting stones were thrown at the police, and prisoner struck the constable with a brick. The Sheriff sentenced him to foir mouth's imprisonment. The trial of two other prisoners was postponed. SHAKESPEARE'S BONES. The Press Association's Stratford-on-Avou correspondent telegraphs that it is authoritatively announced that the Vicar of Stratford-on-Avon is not opposed to the exhumation of Shakespeare's remains for the purpose of comparing the skull with the monumental bust in the church, as pro posed by Dr. Ingleby, one of the life trustees of Shakespeare 8 birthplace. PRINCE BISMARCK AND COUNT KALNOKY. Salzbcrcj, August 30. Prince and Princess Bismarck, accompanied by their son Count Herbert Bismarck, arrived here at half-past one this afternoon and alighted at the Hotel de l'Europe. Count Kalnoky reached this place at three o'clock and was received at the railway station by Count Herbert Bismarck, with whom he proceedeJJat once to the da l'Europe. THE FOOT-AND-MOUTH DISEASE. The foot and-mouth disease is raging very seriously in Huntingdonshire and Northampton- shire. In the latter county, within the Liberty of Peterborough, alone, eighty farms and building* were to-day declared infected places. The look- out for the, stock-breeding interest is therefore very gloomy. The continued prevalence of the same disease in Lincolnshire is a source of much anxiety. There has been an alarming increase in the districts of Spalding and Getney, and more than thirty outbreaks occurred thij week iu a village near Louth. Foot-and mouth disease has again broken out with considerable severity in Leicestershire, it being announced to-day that eighteen parishes are affected. RUTLANDSHIRE ELECTION. THE POLLING. The polling for the seat in Rutlandshire, vacant by the resignation of the Right Hon, Gerard J. Noel (C), opened this morning at four stations, namely — Greetham, Ketton, Oakham, and Uppingham, and during the early hours proceeded very quietly and with great regularity. The Con- servatives wefe the only party using carriages, and there was a great preponderance of yellow (their colour), and very few of the Liberals were wearing colours. The result will be declared to-night. Telegraphing at noon the Press Association Oakham correspondent says matters are still very quiet. Mr. G. H. Finch, M.P., is there assisting Mr. Lowther's candidature. The polling proceeded quietly throughout the day, and the Conservatives claim to have a large majority in the Oakham polling district.

THE VOLCANIC ERUPTION IN JAVA. A telegram received by the Steam Navigation Company, >ederlani, Amsterdam, sent ol fro.n Batavia Ist September at 1.25 r.M., confirms the destruction of Krakatoa and of An.er Ijghthouso, and speaks of rocks unknown so far having •appeared in Sunda Straits, making it necessary to oi ercise the greatest care in passing through the straits. The directors wired at once to Aden to recommend tho master of their steamer S . nda to take the Malacca Straits rather than Sunda. ina steamer Prices Amalia of this line, which has passed Aden, will be warned of events on arrival at Padantr. If anything had happened to the steamer Frinses \Vilhelmina, which reacoea Hatavia on 2Jd August, this telegram sent o.t t>y the company's agent would, the company con- sider, undoubtedly have mentioned the fact.

THE VOLCANIC ERUPTIONS IN JAVA. tt,*^*^ 8 aye been received from correspondents of uxs Daily ir em a t New York of the volcanic eruptions t-v. •!**" appears that the disturbances began on «j«e island of Krakatoa on Saturday, August 25th, when ■*>Prumblings were distinctly audible at Suraperta »nu Batavia. THE VOLCANIC ERUPTIONS. THE DESTRUCTION OF MERAK. The latest telegraphic despatch received by the Dutch Government from tbe scene of the recent volcanic convulsion states tbat no intelligence had arrived at Batavia from tbe Dutch Resident in tbe South Sumatran province of Lampong. It is concluded that Telokbetong has been entirely destroyed. An expedition has left Batavia for Dampong to ascertain the effects of the disaster in that district. The Dutch Cmtroleur a.tK&timbong, which forms the extreme south-eastern point of Lampong, baa been saved, along with all the members of his family. The fact is important as indicating tbat the destruction m that quarter has not been so overwhelming as bad hitherto been apprehended ; that, at any rate, it is not absolute. ■ . , Further particulars bave been received from the Straits showing that at Merak, which waa situated only three milea from Krakatoa, the destruction is complete. Not a vestige of the place now remains. A fort was built there many years ago, and in 1877 extensive quarries were opened in the neighbourhood in order to supply stone for the construction of new piers and doctts in the harbour of Batavia. 'Jbere were other extensive industries carried on at the spot, including railway and ironworks, and there was also a large dynamite store connected witb the quarries The latter were three hundred feet deep, and had within the past five or six years supplied not less than a million and a half tons of rock. Altogether there were some thousands of labourers employed at Merak. They were mostly natives, tbe number of the Europeans having dropped off since the completion of tbe Batavia harbour works. The dwelling-houses, shopp, and business offices stood on an elevated site, about one hundred and fifty feet above tbe level of tbe Bea. Of tbe population of Merak it has now been ascer- tained that, with the exception of one European book- keeper and two natives, every soul has been drowned. There ia not a building left standing, and every bit of property, including all the stores and raw materials, has been completely swept away. In this single spot the loss is estimated at a hundred thousand pounds. With regard to the tidal wave, intelligence has been received from Taudjong Priok, stating that at that place, fifty-eight miles distant from Krakatoa, a sea seven and a half feet higher than the ordinary highest level suddenly rushed in and overwhelmed tbe place. Immediately afterwards it as suddenly sank ten and a half feet below the high-water mark, the effect being most destructive.

THE JAVA ERUPTIONS. The Hague, Tuesday. The Governor-General of the Dutch Indies telegraphed yesterday evening that the extent of the calamity caused by the eruption at Krakatoa is net yet to be estimated, lelok Betong is un- approachable, bnt is probably entirely devastated. From the Resident at the Lampong district no report has been received. An expedition has been sent thither to gain information. The navigation through the Sti alts of Sunda is very dangerous. The vessels of the navy are about to make preliminary surveys, and measures of safety are being taken. The light- houses are still standing at Java's first point and at Ylakke Hoe, but the last named is not lighted. In 'l jiringin 10,000 persons were drowned. The Controller of Katimbant; (south- east point, Lampong districts). Mr. Beyerinck, was saved 'with his family. The Dutch papers contain particulars about the destruction of Merak and its quarries. The commotion of the sea was enormous. At Tandjong Priok, 55 miles from Merak, the water rose to two metres and a fourth above the Batavia tide, and feH more than three metres under that tide. The quarries were in rocks 300 ft. high, the house and office of the engineer being built on a hill 150 ft. beyond the sea. All this, with the whole population of work- men, was swallowed up by the sea.

THE EARTHQUAKE IN JAVA. 100,000 Lives Lost. Little additional news has been received respecting the terrihle natural convulsion in Java. It is not yet possible to collect the data on which a trustworthy calculation oan be founded, but in any case the loss of life is expected by competent judges to turnout vastly larger than any estimate hitherto published. In North Bantam there were till recently half a million Javanese inhabitants, but a considerable migration has taken place, owing to the diminishing productivity of the soil of late years. Nevertheless, it is considered probable that from eighty to one hundred thousand natives bave perished in this district, as the population of Anjer and Tjiringen alone was nearly sixty thousand. From telegrams despatched from Yew York it appears that the disturbances began on the island of Krakatoa on Saturday, August 25th, when distinct rumblings were audible at Suraperta and Batavia. Little alarm was felt at first, but within a few hours showers of stones began to fall, and all through the night showers of red hot stones and ashes fell. The temperature of tbe sea rose nearly twenty degrees and the waters were boiling and hissing violently. By noon Maha Meiu, the largest of the volcanoes, was belching forth flames at an alarming rate. This eruption soon spread to Gunung Guntur and other mountains until more than, a third of the forty- five craters of Java were either in active eruption or threatening it. Just before dusk the crater of Gunung Guntur began to emit enormous streams of white and sul phurous mud and lava, rapidly succeeded by explosions followed by tremendous showers of cinders and enormous fragments of rock. With these terrible eruptions came sympathetic demonstrations from the sea and at one time more than fifteen huge waterspouts were seen. Men, women and children rushed in terror from their tottering dwelling places, filling the air with shrieks of horror. Hundreds were unable to get out before tbe houses fell and were buried beneath great masses of rocks and mud. On Monday it was seen that a large tract of land— oovering about 50 square miles—had disappeared. Sumatra as well as Java appears to have been visited by the earthquake. A ship has been sent from Batavia to Lampong in Sumatra, where the situation of things is most horrible. For a distance exceeding five miles every- thing had been destroyed, aud many thousands of lives have been lost. _ The native population are furious against the Dutch, believing that the calamity is a punishment from Heaven for the war in Acheen ; and it is found to be dangerous for any European to approach the people. This statement, however, requires confirmation, as the Lampongs are naturally a very timid race ; and probably the present excitement is a consequence of the priests working upon the fanaticism of their followers. The lighthouse at Lampong has not yet been relighted. A telegram received by the Nederland Steamship Co., dated Batavia. August 31st, says that the Straits Govern- ment have offered $25,000, and the Java Government 5,000 guilders towards the relief oi the distress caused by the earthquake. A communication from the Secretary of the Admiralty states that H.M.S. "Champion," H.M.S. "Magpie," and H.M.S. " Flying Fish," are to proceed to the Strait of Sunda to survey the changes which have been made in the navigation by the earthquake and the tidal wave of the 29th of August last.

THE AWFUL VOLCANIC ERUPTIONS IN JAVA. TERRIBLE SCENES. IMMENSE DESTRUCTION OF TOWNS. A HUNDRED THOUSAND LIVES LOST. { ISLANDS COMPLETELY ENGULFED. Batavia, Aug. 30. Sixteen volcanoes have appeared between the site 1 where Krakatoa stood and Sibisio Island. The Soen- 1 Kenan volcano has split into five. A portion of the : Presidency of Bantam is now an ashy desert. Cattle | are without food, and the population in despair. Dead bodies are now being recovered inthe district of Tanara; 704 have already been buried at Kramat, and 300 in the district of Serang Fort. Tjiringen Telokbetong, with the lighthouses there and at Anjer, have been destroyed. Krakatoa has disappeared. Sixteen islets j have risen. Five European functionaries have perished, i Batavia, Aug. 31. There is no news from the Sumatra coast. In some places masses of floating pumice stone, seven feet in depth, were passed. In the district of Tjiringen the los 3 of life is estimated at 10,0' JO. Some estimates place the total loss of life in tho Straits through the eruption at over 30,000. The Comptroller and Assistant Resident at Tjiringen, together with a lieutenant employed in the Topographic Service, were among those who perished by the eruption. Search is still being made for five Europeans known to have been at Anjer at the time of the eruption. Two vessels of the American squadron in Asiatic waters have been ordered to proceed to the Straits of Sunda to examine the state of affairs, (Daily Newt Telegram. ) New York, Sept. 2. The disturbances began on the island of Krakatoa on Saturday, August 2"jth, when deep rumblings were distinctly audible at Suraperta and Bntavia. Little ! alarm was felt at first, but within a few hours showers ef stones began to fall, and all through the ni?bt showers of red-hot stones and ashes fell. By morn- ing all communications with Anjer on the Strait i of Sunda were destroyed, bridges being wrecked and roads rendered impassable. Tiie disturbances had extended beneath the waters of the Strait, and they were boiling and hissing violently, while great waves dashed on Java's shores. The temperature of the sea rose nearly 20 degrees. Far away at Madura, more than 300 miles distant, furious waves were lashed into mountains of foam as they came rolling in. The rumblings gradually became more and more dis- tinct, and by noon of the same day Maha Meru, the Im-gest of ths volcanoes, was belching forth flames at an alarming rate. This eruption soon spread to Gunung (luntur, and many other minor mountains, until more tiian a third of the 45 craters ot Java were either in active eruption or seriously threatening it. Just before dusk a great luminous cloud formed over Gunung Guntur. and the crater of that volcano began to emit euorrnous streams of white and sulphurous mud and lava, which were rapidly succeeded by explosions, followed by tremendous showers of cinders and enor- mous fragments of rock, which were hurled high into the air and scattered in all directions, carrying death and destruction with them. With these terrible erup- ' tions came sympathetic demonstrations from tiie sea. Overhanging clouds were so surcharged with electricity that at one time more than fifteen huge waterspouts were i een. Men. women, and children rushed in terror from their tottering dwelling-places, filling the air with shrieks of horror. Hundreds were unable to get out before the houses fell, and weie buried beneath great masses of rocks and mud. On Sunday evening, the shocks and eruptions increased in violence, and ihe island seemed threatened with submersion. At the s une time enormous waves began to dash with greater force upon the shores, coming in some p'.aces far up into the interior ; and great chasms opened in thi earth, threatening to engulf the people and buildings. . About midnight the most frightful scene of all took place. Suddenly an enorm- ous luminous cloud, similar to that over Gun- ung Guntur, but much greater in extent, formed over the Kandang range of mountains which skirt the south-east coast of the island. This cloud gradually increased in size until it formed a canopy lurid red cad whitish gray over a wide extent of territory. During this time the eruptions increased, and streams of lava poured incessantly down the sides of the mountains into the valleys, sweeping everything before them. About two o'cioc on Monday morning, this great cloud suddenly broke into small sections and vanished, and when daylight came it was seen that an enormous tract of land had disappeared, extending from Point Capucin, on the south, to Negery Passoerang, on the north and west, to the lowest point, covering about 50 square miles. Here were situated the villages of Negery and Negerj Babawang. : None of the inhabitants of these places escaped death. This section of the island was less densely populated than the other portions, and the loss of life was com- paratively small, although it must have aggregated 15,000. The entire Kandang range of mountains, ex- tending along the coast in a semicircle for about 6.> miles, bad gone out of sight. The waters of Welcome Bay, in the Sunda Straits, and Pepper-Bay on the east, and tbe Indian Ocean on the south, had rushed in and formed a sea of turbulent waters. (>n Monday night, tbe volcano of Papandayang was in an active state of paroxysmal eruption, which Was accompanied by detonations which are said to have been heard for many miles away. In Sumatra three distinct j columns of flame were seen to rise from a mountain to I a vast height, and its whole surface was soon covered with fiery lava streams which spread to great dis- j tancss on ail sides. Stones fell for miles around, and i black fragmentary mattsr carried into the air j caused total darkness. A whirlwind accompanied i this eruption, by which house-roofs, trees, | men, and horses were carried into the air. The quantity of ashes ejected was such as to cover the ground and the roots of the houses at Denamo to the depth of several inches. Suddenly the scene changed. The mountain was split into seven parts without a moments warning, and where Papan- daying had stood alone were now seven distinct peaks, in the opening seams of which could be seen great balls of molten matter. From the fissures poured forth clouds cf steam and black lava, which flowing in steady streams, ran slowly down the mountain sides, i forming beds 200 or 300 feet in extent. One of the most singular incidents was the sudden rising on the forenoon of Tuesday of 14 new volcanic mountains in the Straits of Svmda, forming a complete chain in almost a straight line betweet Point St. Nicholas on the Java coast, and Hoga Point on the coast of Sumatra, almost on the tops of what had been Merak and Middle Islands, which Stmk into the sea on the previous day. At the entrance to Batavia was a large group of houses extending along the shore, aud occupied by Chinamen. This portion of j the city was entirely destroyed, and of 25,000 Chinese who lived on tiie swampy plains, it is hardly probable tbat more than 5,000 managed to save their lives. They stuck to their homes till the waves.came and washed them away, fearing torrents of flame and lava more than torrents of water. Of the 3,500 Europeans and 'Ymericans in Batavia, |00 perished at Anjer. The European and American j quarter was first overwhelmed by rocks, mud, and lava j from the crater, and then the waters came up and swallowed the ruins, leaving nothing to mark the site, and causing the loss of about 200 ItVes of the inhabit- ants and those who sought refuge there. Bantam was entirely' covered by water, and .1,200 to 1,500 are be- lieved to have been drowned. The island of Serang j was completely inundated, and not a soul sur- Tired. At Cheribon there was no great flood of water, but the loss of life and property by falling looks and lava must have been considerable, j BirtinzoDg suffered seriously, as did Samarang, Jog- i jakerta, Sourakerta, and Sourabaya. The thousand ! temples at Brambaman were greatly damaged, and seme of them destroyed. The dome of the noted Temple of Borobodo was crushed in by falling rocks. The town of Tamerang was swept away by lava, and fully half the population, mostly Javanese, numbering about 1,800, perished. At Speezwyk, red-hot rocks set fire to the houses and swept away all the thickly- settled portions of the town. About 10 bazaars belong- ing to Europeans were destroyed. The river Jacatana, on the banks of which Batavi* is situated, was so com- pletely dammed by lava and debris that its course was changed, and from Franien Bastion it flowed down through Tygers Street and joined the waters of the River Emerades, swelling that stream to such an ex- tent that it rose high on the Castor batteries. Figelenking was almost totally destroyed, and a large number of lives lost. Tha island of Onius, five miles off of the mouth of the Targerang River, and 20 miles east of Batavia, was completely inundated and the boating dock totally destroyed. Baby and Cheriboo islands lost a few houses and inhabitants upon them. In Batavia tho roof of tha Governor's house was crushed in by a mass of mud, and three servants were killed. Midah Island, 10 miles off on the coast of Java, was almost wholly engulfed. The towns of Anjer, Tjiringine, and Telokbelong are reported as destroyed, and all lighthouses alone: tho Sunda Strait have disap- peared. The aspect of the Strait is much changed, and the navigation is dangerous. Some 900 inhabitants of the town of Waronge are known to have been killed, and at Talatoa, on the coast, 300 bodies have been found. From all over the island come reports of loss of life f-.nd property, and it is thought that the estimate of 75,000 will not prove excessive. On the lowlands of Eatavia, where the waters have receded, hundreds of bruised and mangled bodies are lying exposed. Amsterdam, Sept. 3. It is not yet possible to collect tho data on which a trustworthy calculation can be founded. In any case the loss of life is expected by competent judges to turn out vastly larger than any estimate hitherto published. In North Bantam there were till recently half-a-million Javanese inhabitants, but a considerable migration has taken place, owing to the diminishing productivity of tho soil or" late years. Nevertheless, it is considered pro- bable that from SO,OOO to 100,000 natives have perished in this district, as the population of Anjer and Tjiringen alone was nearly CO,OOO. An extensive plain of volcanic stone has been formed in the sea near Lam- pong, Sumatra, which renders communication impos- sible with Telokbetong aad the south-west of Java. The Hague, Sept. 4. An official despatch states that Telok Ectong, in Sumatra, has probably been totally destroyed. No news has bean received from Lampong. At Tjivirgen 10,000 were drowned.
article title: THE AWFUL VOLCANIC ERUPTIONS IN JAVA.

text: THE DESTRUCTION OF MERAK. Amsterdam, Aug. 4. No intelligence has arrived at Batavia from the Dutch Residents in tho South Suraatran province of Lampong. It is concluded that Telokbetong has been entirely destroyed. The " First Point," Java, and the " Vlakke Hock" Lighthouses are still in existence, but the light in the latter is no longer burning. The Dutch Conlroleur at Hatimbong, which forms the extreme south-eastern point of Lampong, has been saved, along with all the members of his'family. The fact is im- portant as indicating that the destruction in that quarter has not been so overwhelming as had hitherto been apprehended ; that, at any rate, it is not absolute. Further particulars havo been received from t>j» «wa!tt .wowing that at MaraV. which -wxh situated only three miles from Erakakoa, the destruction is complete. Not a vestige of the place now remains. A fort was built there many years sgo, and in 1877 extensive quarries were opened in the neigh- bourhood in order to supply stone for the construction of the new piers and dock 3 in the harbour of Batavia. There were other extensive industries carried on at the | spot, including railway and ironworks, and there was I also a large dynara'te store connected with the quarries. 1 The latter were 300 feet deep, and had within the past five or six years supplied not less i than a million and a-half tons of rock. Altogether i there were some thousands of labourers employed at i Merak. They were mostly natives, the number of the ; Europeans having dropped off since , the completion of | the Batavia harbour works. The dwelling-houses, ' shops, and business offices stood on an elevated site, about 150 feet above tho level of the sea. Of tho ' population of Merak it has now been ascertained that, with th* exception of one European book- keeper and two natives, every soul has been : drow.ied. There is not a building left ! standing, and every bit of property, including all the ! stores and raw materials, has been completely swept '. away. In this single spot the loss is estimated at a hundred thousand pounds. With regard to the tidal wave, intelligence have been received from Taudiong Priok, stating that at thatpiace, 58 miles distant from | Krakatoa, a sea seven and a-half feet higher than the ordinary highest level, suddenly rushed in and over- whelmed the place. Immediately afterward it as suddenly sank ten and a-half feet below the h'gh-water mark, the effect being most destructive.

The ftmeraT eorttye was very imposing. It comprised the members ef afl tWe Cbrpsra- tions of the town, including the Association df tetferans, the benevolent societies, and Various confraternities, ail bearing tapers. The cause of their absence, it is said, is that the Comtesse de Chambord insisted that Don Carlos should'take the fbremost place among the representatives »f the family of the an arrangement which was strenuously opposed by tho Comte de Pmrls and the Duo i'Aumale. As the Comtesse de Ghambord was not to be persuaded to alter the decision she had formed, the two Princes of Orleans preferred to stay away altogether from the ceremony. Madagascar.—Durban, Aug. 31 ( Times). — The Taymouth Castle has arrived here from Mauritius and Madagascar. Her commander could not communi- cate with Tamatave. The town is still occupied by the French. Admiral Pierre is at Reunion, waiting for a steamer to proceed to France. Ho is said to From ophthalmia. Mr. Shaw, the miscktimry, is a pas- senger on board the Tayinonth Castle for Kngland. He complains bitterly of the treatment which he received while on board the French flagship. The French state- nmt that several engagements were fought at Tamatave, in which the Hovas were defeated, with loss, is not to be iltogether depended upon.—Messrs. Donald Currie and Ik), have received the following telegram from Natal, respecting the steamship Taymouth Castle, which arrived there on Friday morning from Mauritius: —"Taymouth Castle was at Tamatave 11th inst. Shipped distressed British subjects. Missionaries reached Mauritius by schooner. Now on Taymonth. Aug. 31." PIBTHdtaABITZBCRG, Sept. 2 (Daily NewsJ.—the Taymouth dropped the mail on Friday at Dnrban with- out communicating further. She proceeds immediately to the Cape. Mr. Shaw is on board. He was kept a dose prisoner on the French flagship for over two months, being brought thrice to trial before the Naval Court, ind ultimately discharged. He was denied all papers and books except the bible. The offence charged against him was not stated. Paris, Sept. I.—An official despatch from Tamatave ilated August 26 confirms the news of the death of the tjueen of the Hovas, which took place on the 13th of July. She has been succeeded by her niece, who takes the title of Queen Ranavalo 111. The Prime Minister remains in power. The Pietennaritzburg correspondent of the Daily News tends the first authenticated narrative of Mr. Shaw's treatment at the hands of the French in Madagascar. Ihe substance of Mr. Shaw's case, which he has for- warded to the Imperial Government, is that he was charged falsely with harbouring spies, and wa* impri- lened ashore. He was then taken on board the Nievre, ind charged with attempting to poison the French troops. Twenty-two days after the first charge was made he was charged with another offence. He was never tried by court-martial, but was periodically exa- mined on freshly trumped-up accusations. When finally released he was on the verge of starvation. Zulttland.—Durban, Sept. 1 (Times). — About 400 men of the 41st Regiment, including mounted infantry, are now marching from Verulam to Stanger, 15 miles this side of the Lower Tugela. Their final destina- tion is kept secret. Colonel Montgomery is in command. Stanger is 50 miles from Middle Drift, beyond which is Inkankla Bush, the place of Cetewayo's refuge. In the absence of official tidings it is difficult to know what is actually going on. A private correspondent at Inkankla, writing on August 19, says that Mr.Osborne waited three days to see the King, when a letter was sent for Mr. Osborne. Cetewayo, however, fled into the bush when the Resident, with a small mounted escort, came in view of the kraal. As armed parties seemed to be gathering en the hill-tops around, Mr. Osborne deemed it prudent to return. The Ekowe Usutu partjr are rallying again in the relerve, it is reported, with a view of proceeding again against Usibepu. The latter is said to have killed Sotkele, a chief, near St. Lucia Bay, destroying and dispersing his tribe. Europeans in Zululand maintain that the only way to establish peace is an armed occupa- tion of the Reserve, whither Vmnyamana and Umlabuko are on their way to join the King. The Pietermaritzburg correspondent of the Daily News telegraphs:—The followers of Onyanaa, the Prime Minister, are crossing into the reserve by ones and twos. This gives rise to the suspicion that the case of that chief is hopeless. Carnage and plunder continue. Hlubi has, under orders, mustered his fighting men. It is believed that a combined movement is to be made to disband the armed party with Cetewayo. Durban, Sept. 5 (Jleuter). —Cetewayo, at the head of a strong force, is still in the Reserve territory. He maintains a defiant attitude towards Mr. Osborn, the British Resident, and declines all intervention of the colonial authorities. The Zulu King has summoned the Usutus to join him. Afghanistan.—Calcutta, Sept. 2 ( Times). — It was rumoured here last week that the Important tribe of the Ghilzais had risen against the Ameer. There was no trnth in the report. The Ghilzais are doubtless dis- contented at the Ameer's having raised their tribute, snd held them responsible for the raid made recently on a caravan near Jagdalak. But Mag Mahomed Khan, one of their leading chiefs, has just waited on the Ameer at Mama-Khel; and Khan Mahomed Khan, another important chief, has started to try and recover the pro- perty for which the tribe is held answerable. Many other influential Ghilzais are with the Ameer. There have been disturbances among the Zurmat and Kullowaz, in which Mushk-i-Alim is believed to have been impli- aited ; but General Katab Khan, with a small force, easily quelled them, destroying many forts, among them that of Mushk-i-Alim. The rumour of the Ameer's assassination appears to have been started by some lervants of the British Envoy, Afzul Khan, who bad been dismissed and sent back to Peshawur. Italy and Mobocco.—Gibraltar, Aug. 31. — The Italian war vessel Barbarigo arrived at Tangier on Wednesday last from All Zali with Sid Suiesi, the Governor of Rabat, on board. The latter on landing proceeded to the Italian Embassy, and before all the Italian officers there present offered an apology to Signor Scovasso, the Italian Envoy, as satisfaction for illegal lets committed against Italian subjects in Morocco. The ipology having been accepted, the difficulty between Italy and Morocco is believed to be nearly settled.— Tangier, Aug. 31.—The demands of Italy have been uartly conceded by Morocco, and a complete peaceful settlement of the difficulty between the two countries is shortly expected Hungary.—Vienna, Aug. 31.—1n Hungary the bands of rioters not only commit robberies, but set bouses on fire, and murder the Jews that fall into their hands. Two villages have been entirely burned down. Fires break out simultaneously in several places, and never anywhere but in the houses of Jews. Enormous quantities of corn have been burns 1. The outrages have been carefully planned. They were to commence all at unce at the annual market of Egerczeg, but bands of young men out of work, who call themselves Hungarian Kihilists, hurried matters on. At Szentpeter on the night jf the 29th a merchant wait robbed and then murdered. 1 lie son of an old Jew whom masked men were murder- ing managed to save his mother and bis sisters by shoot- mg the aggressors, whose bodies the mob carried off. Hundreds of Jews fled to Kanissa, leaving their property behind. Some of the reports, however, must be received with caution. According to one, some houses were set "ii tire, and the Jews thrown into the flames. In some 'uses respectable persons mingled with the plundarerg, and the next day returned all they could lay their hands <«n to those who had been robbed. The Jews are urged to remain in their homes, and to make use of firearms. The Volcanic Eruption in Java.—Batavia, August 29 (Reuter). —Sixteen volcanoes have appeared between the site where Krakatoa stood and Sibisle Island. The Soengepan volcano has split into five. A portion of the Residency of Bantam is an ashy desert. The cattle are without food, and the population m lespair.—August 90 : Dead bodies are now being re- covered. In the district of Tanara 704 have already been buried, in the coast village of Kramat 300, mostly Chinese, and in the district of Seraiig 40. On the 27th August a tidal wave from 12 to 30 mitres in height swept the coast of Merak as far as Tniringin. The towns jf Arijer, Merak, and Ttdringin were overwhelmed, together with all the Government buildings ; and the lighthouses at Vierdepunt, in Java, and Vlakkebock, in Sumatra, were likewise destroyed. The aspect of the Straits of Sunda has undergone a complete transformation. .Batavia, August 31.—There is no news from the Sumatra coast. The destruction of Tolott-Betong was reported by the captain of the steamship Governor- General. London, belonging to Batavia, who was at sea Ut the height of the eruption, and steamed to AnJer to ?ive the alarm, but found that place destroyed. His ship had a layer of ashes 18 inches thick on her deck. In some places masses of floating pumice-stone seven feet in depth were passed. In the district of Tjiringen the loss of life is estimated at 10,000. Some estimates place the total loss of life in the Straits through the eruption at over 30,000. ■' < Probably no volcanic eruptions in the world have been physically so terrible as some of these In Java, though •>'e Italian eruptions have brokon in more conspicuously on the art and civilisation of the world.
