Boston, Deo. 8,188% Sir,—Will yon as the. oonductor of an old-ertjjUdished oouuty newspaper having a reputation for respectability and sobriety of language admit a gentle remonstrance ajgainst the invective and personal abuse which distinguishes a portion of the local press of this town—a licentiousness faring a tendency to keep alive the bitter feeling between opposing parties which hss been fully prouunent since the last- municipal, elections, in most plyw a<ter the excitement of an election contest people sink their tapj»rary antagonism, and amicably admit that differences of opinion should not uproot friendship; but here unfortunately no sentiment of the kind is allowed to epithets that are offensive to all well constituted minds are indulged in in print to the annoyance and^ disgust of tho respectable portion of the community, who feel that tna use of gross personalities has a tendency to bring disgrace onthe character of the town where theficence ofttieprMS is so abused. This licence may be relished by pubhe-house disputants; but from what I know of the more enlightened of our inhabitants, I am sure the course pursued is indig- nantly condemned as a deplorable thit thU rivalor. The parties concerned may not be aware that Wis feeling extensively prevails in respectable society; and trust that if you will give publicity to the fact my re- monstrance may have the effect of correcting the e^ij. Yours respectfully, A Liberal Conservative. Agricultural Holdings Aat, 1883. To the EDITOR of the MERCURY. Sir, —At the special general meeting of the members of tne Lincolnshire Chamber of Agriculture and the Land Agents' and Tenants' Rights Valuers' Association, held at Lincoln on the 30th of November, it was resolved That in the opinion of this meeting it is desirable to adopt the undermentioned scale of allowances as fair and reasonable compensation under part 3 of the first schedule of the Agricultural Holdings Act, 1883, to be substituted by agree- ments for compensation under the Act, viz. 1. ror one-third of the cost of linseed cake, cotton cake, rape cake, or malt culm, and one-sixth of the cost of corn cake, malt, or other manufactured feeding stuffs of similar inanurwl vahu, which have been consumed on the farm during tne last year of the tenancy; and for one-sixth of the cost of linseed cake, cotton cake, rape cake, or malt culm, and one- twelfth of the cost of corn cake, malt or other inamijacturecl feeding stuffs of similar manurial value which shall have been consumed on the farm during the preceding year of the tenancy. , , . ~ . I write to ask the meaning of the words above in italics, ana to what they refer ? How far do they go 1 I consider them very vague and unsatisfactory. Out other munv i f(ictuT€d fccdwm stuffs may be counted on the fingers of one hand. Why, then, are they not enumerated ? Do they refer to lamb food. In my opinion the most valuable autumn food for lambs ever invented. Do they refer to barley meal? Every farmer uses some, many6ome thousands of stones a year, in the feeding of pigs, &c. My experience teaches me that pig manure beats all other for sand land, and is as good as most others for any kind of land. Is oatmeal or crushed oats included? If not they ought to be; it grows young stock better than any other food, it is safer than any other, and its manurial value is quite as great as the allowance. Is the desirable but diuretic pea, the feeding but flatulent bean, to be left out in the cold ? I hope not; they are exceed- ingly rich in nitrogen, and consequently invaluable as an assistant food and as manure. Will maize be allowed for ? 1 was very much amused at the meeting of the Chamber of Agriculture a few weeks ago, to which friends were invited, to see the expression of pious horror depicted on the face and in the uplifted hands of an "Old Fogie," who declared "We can't admit maize; our cart horses eat it." This was in answer to a proposed but not seconded resolu- tion, that maize be inserted instead of malt and corn cakc ; thus trying to still further play into the foreigners' hands. If maize isof any manurial value, and in the lasttrialsat Wobum it has beaten the very much Voelcker-vaunted decorticated cottoncakes. What think you to that, my countrymen? And asaflcsh-formeritbeat it hollow, as everyone mightexpect it would. Considering that our cart horses spend 10 hours in the stable, seven on the farm, and one on the roads, we have submitted quite long enough to the unjust practice of having the cake they consume all strictly deducted from valuations. The old Lincolnshire tenant-right custom has lost this county thousands of pounds a year in moat alone through encouraging the use of cotton and rape and discouraging the use of our home-grown feeding stuffs, and many more thousands still have, from the same causc, been put into the foreigners' pockets which now would have been more appreciated by landlords and tenants alike had they been left in our own. If this suicidal policy- had not been in vogue, would oats and grinding barley be at 9d. a stone ? I think not. I wish to extend and not curtail the privileges of the farmers, and there is no privilege they enjoy so much as that of grumbling, and no grumbling they practice more than against the Government of the day for fostering foreign trade at the expense of our own produc- tions. If we do not insist on home produce being put on the same footing as foreign in our tenant rights, we must rendar ourselves liable to the retort " that season comes, Wherein our Saviour's birth is celebrated." (I hope I may be pardoned using it.) First cast out the beam that is in thine own eye, then shalt thou see to pull out the mote that is in thy brother's (Government's) eye.—l thank you for the insertion of this letter, and remain, sir, j'Our obedient servant, W. Tavlor Bh.arfe. Bavmber Parle, Horncastle, December 10,1833.

1883. THE STORY OF THE YEAR. THE CITIZEN, MONDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1883. The Curfew this evening will toll the knell of the parting year 1883, and to-morrow we start upon a New Tear with its doubts and fears, its hopes and expecta- tions. The year 1883 is not conspicuous for events so great as those, which in the year preceding, onlminated | in the disastrous Tel-el-Kebir. But it has been aba y j and eventful one at home. Politics and political , measures of reform have been eagerly discussed both ] when Parliament was sitting aud during the recess, j During the whole year Ireland has been a sore thorn , in the side of the Government, and it is still confronted , with problems as great and complicated as ever per- , plexei the minds of Statesmen. At the end of last year some improvement was noticed in the internal stats of Ireland through the vigorous enforcement of the Crimes Act by Lord Spenoer and Mr. Trevelyan, and agrarian crime and bojojttiug had partially ceattd. Than Veto the workingof the Land Act the improvement is maintained, and rents are paid with tolerable regularity. There are but few signs that indicate, however, that the general feeling of the Irish people is changed towards the English ; and the presentation of £40,000 recently made to Mr. Parnell could not possibly have been raised among so poor a people had not the Irish peasantry so bitterly detested those who have strived hard to help them. Mr. Parnell attacks this country more virulently than ever, and has again and again repeated that Ireland rrill not be sati fied even with Home Rule. What they aim at is a sever- ance of every bond of union between the two countries. The North of Ireland has been disturbed by revolutions ; but they have not made much way. Sir Stafford Northcote visited Ulster, and the loyal population, endeavoured to efface the impression produced by hia visit. This little incident was not lost upon the English, for it reminded us that there are really two parties in Ireland, and oivil war is not entirely out of the question. The American-Irish party, too, has done its best to alarm us. O'Donovan Rosea and his accom- plices talk openly and in the market place of the most atrocious crimes. These threats were more than idle words for on the 15th March an attempt was made to blow up the Times and Local Government Board offices whioh were considerably damaged. The police became vigilant and bands of conspirators were arrested in Birmingham and London. England appreciated the danger she was in, and a bill amending the existing law as to explosives, was introduced and passed in a fewhcurs. The dynamite method of upholding Irish ideaß is stili to be guarded againßt, ani the recent explosion npon the Underg<ound Railway warns us of the power of ruffians. It is not creditable to Irish leaders that, they have nothing to my against this wholesale mur- dering of innocent men, women and children. The murder of Carey, with all its horrible details, is still too- green in people's memory. O'Donnell was tried, con- demned, hanged ; and so ends, we hope, one of the foulest incidents in Irish history. Some Ministerial changes at the close of last year resulting from Mr. Gladstone's resignation of the Exohequer, an exchange of offices between Mr. Childers, Lord Kimberly, Lord Hartington, and Mr. Dodson, and the admission to the Cabinet of Lord Derby and Sir Charles Dilke, were completed at the beginning of January. Lord E. Fitzmaurice became Under-Secretary at the Foreign Office, and Mr. Brand, son of the Speaker, was made Surveyor-General of the Ordnance. Some months later, on the resignation of Lord Rosebery, Mr. Hibbert was appointed Under- Secretary for the Home Department, and a place was found for Mr. George Russell as Secretary of the Local Government Board. But in its essential composition the Administration remained unchanged throughout tha year. When Parliament was opened on the 15th of February, although the condition of Ireland was very far from satisfactory, it- was deemed expedient to give some time and attention to the needs of England and Scotland. The Parlia- mentary Sessions of the year have not a happy history. In spite of new rules of procedure and an unlimited power invested with the Speaker by the cloture motion, many debates were prolonged to a tedious length, and many evenings spent in acrid and fruitless "jaw." StU t. some useful measv lwere passed, and the system of Grand Comnv* ' so successful that they may be co""' ercentive development. •>eas n re whioh became designed for usation for also much '. The Bill re excited aa York elections, lany cabmen at York refused to vote for the Liberal candidate because the Liberal Government had robbed them of " turning an honest penny." A Nationa Debt was adopted, and the Bankruptcy Bill, which was so expeditiously managed by Mr. Chamberlain, met with general approval in both Houses. The Deceased Wife's Sister Bill was read a second time in the House of Lords, and on a third reading was rejected by a small majority. A Bill for the suppression of pigeon shooting was got through iv the Commons, but rejected in the Upper House. One of the longest and most exciting debates of the Session related to the Affirmation Bi'l„ when Mr. Gladstone made a strong speech in favour of it. There were for the Bill 289 votes, against 292. Thus Mr. Bradlaugh is still excluded from his seat, and some trouble may yet be expeoted from the member for Northampton. Bat politics and discussions on measures brought forward by the Government have raged with greater force outside the doors of the House than within. During the recess both parties have shown unwonted activity. The Prime Minister, in the midst of the labours of the Session, encouraged his party in a powerful speech delivered at the opening of the National Liberal Club ; Mr. Chamberlain, both before and afterwards, has boldly carried the war " into Africa," denouncing those " who toil not, neither de they spin,"' with special application to the peers and individually to Lord Salisbury. On the other hand the Conservative chiefs were not less energetic and aggressive. Lord Salisbury and Sir Stafford Northcote, as well as others of less conspicuous and responsible position, seized every opportunity of placing their views before the country. On both sides the exigencies of party masterel any differences of opinion and personal jealousies. It was noted that this session was the first since the General Election in which the Government had lost none of its members through a disagreement on matters of policy, for Lord Roeebert's resignation, avowedly to facilitate the Ministerial arrangements, was not to be compared with the successive losses of the Marquis of Lausdowne, the Duke of Argyll, Mr. Forster, and Mr. Bright. Both parti's seem to feel that next Session will be a» critical one. Conservatives attack the whole Liberal policy at home and abroad, especially denouncing the conduct of affairs in Ireland. Egypt, and South Af rica r Liberals believed they had a good defence to make on all points, but to " make assurance doubly sure," a con- ference of thg representatives of Liberal organizations was held at Leeds, at which it was resolved, in spite of the objections urged by those interested in the abolition, of the old Corporation of London and of the exiatingr administrative authorities in the counties, to insist that the Government give precedence next year to the promised measure of Parliamentary reform. The cry of '• Reform" became the Liberal watch- word. Conservatives have maintained an attitude of B cautious observation," a policy commended to hie friends subsequently by Sir Stafford Northcote, but not oae calculated to produce a striking effect upon public opinion. Even the more energetic spokesmen of the Opposition, Lord Salisbury in England and Mr. Gibson in Scotland, contented themselves with suggesting difficulties aud demanding that the- j whole of the Government scheme thould be I disclosed before a decisive judgment was de- manded upon it from Parliament and the country. | A Franchise Bill is to be introduced next Session, but ; it is not a decided question whether the measure should be accompanied by a Redistribution measure, \ or that the same franchise should extend to England, Scotland, and Ireland. La.'ely, also, of the housing of the poor has excited a good deal of interest. It was discussed in an able article from the pen of ! Lord Salisbury in the Nat onal Review, and answered by a less temperate, but equally able, reply from Mr. Chamberlain, who made it a text for an attack on the landowning classes, 'on whom he proposed to throw the charge of removing insanitary dwellings and replacing them by good houses built under municipal direction. The subject is still left, as the houses, in a most unsatisfactory state, and fresh legislation is not considered advisable until the question has been thoroughly investigated by a Royal Commission. On this question Sir C. Pilke has made himself much respected by his administrative ability In the spring Lord Randolph Churchill made himself notorious and raised a deal of discussion relative to a letter to the Timet on Conservative leadership. Lord Randolph still acknowledges both Sir Stafford Northcote and Lord Silisbnry as chief. To from the last Parlia- mentary return, Mr. Gladstone's Government is not so popular as it was ; but the head of the Government is still regarded with great enthusiasm— witness the beautiful gift just presented to him by the Liberal working-men of Derby. Of foreign affairs France claims tha greatest share of attention. The extraordinary and almost phenomenal methods of procedure employed by her Governors nearly ended in the disruption of the Repubhoan party, a fact which was only averted by the folly of Prince Napoleon. France is everywhere in hot, water, and stands almost isolated among European nations. After the excitement caused by the death of M Gambetta (when France seemed to be hopelessly stranded),and the issue of a manifestation by Prince Napoleon, M. Doolero resigned the office of Prime Minister and M. Julei Ferry reigned in his stead. In home affairs he has pursued a moderate and unobtrusive -olicy ; but in foreign affairs, he has shown a restlessness and desire for aggrandisement nneqsalled by any of his Republican predecessors. In Madagascar a controversy with the Hova Government in Madagascar had arisen the year before, and in the spring Admiral Pierre's squadron was sent out to re- establish "French rights" over the north-west of the island. The Admiral bombarded and held the port of Tamatave, and the Btress of these measures was chiefly felt by the European residents, for the most part English merchants or missionaries. The Hovas at once retired into the interior, where the French appear to have been unable fer months past to make any further impression upon them. Admiral Pierre acted with insolence towards British residents, and towards Captain Johnstone of the Dryad, whose deck was once cleared for action. Then follows the story of the treatment of the Rev. G. Shaw, and his trial for an alleged attempt to poison French sailors. The rest of this deplorable incident is well known. The French Government ultimately (and ungraciously) compensated the reverend gentleman, and pacified the English Government by an explanation. M. Ferry too, was possessed of astrongdesire to occupy Tonquin, and to establish a protectorate (or annex) the King- dom of Anam. China has resisted French pretensions, and the latest intelligence iB tbat Admiral Courbet has captured SonVay, and is advancing upon Bac-Ninh, the seizure of whioh fortress the Marqiis Tseng has declared will be considered a eatus belli by tha Chinese. Frarjce has made herself disliked by her treatment of King Alfomo, when he paid a royal visit to their capital. By their insult, however, France did good service to the insulted, for it hea'ed tbe slight breach between Alfonso and the Spanish people. Things are still unsatisfactory in Egypt. The Egyptians complain that we will not let them alone, nor give them that vigorous support without which the State cannot be properly re-organised. In the Soudan, the army of Hic'ts Pasha, which went to suppress the Mahdi, was annihilated ; and British troops are retained at Cairo. ' J ,fc ahnn]d stated, disapproved of the at and Egypt will not be enco. conau' , «t of a countr* which e^ be incapable of holding. • desolated by cholera which About 27,000 persons died of tl In India there has been considerable commotion upon the Ilbert Bill, whioh has been resisted by the whole Anglo-Indian population. It is for the purpose of conferring on a limited class of native judges, jurisdic- tion over British subjects. Happily a compromise has been arrived at. Zululand is still unsettled, and the fate of its King trembles in the balance. The Boers crave absolute freedom, and delegates from the Transvaal have waited upon Lord Derby, and oontinue to do so without any apparent result. England intends to redume her protectorate of the Basuto tribes, which is the only satisfactory news from South Africa. In Australasia, the event of 1883 is the annexation of New Guinea. Lord Lome has been succeeded by Lord Lanßdowne as Governor-General of Canada; and nothing has happened this year to check the growing prosperity of the dominion. Germany is still in high repute, and beyond now and then throwing out a nasty lance against France, Prince Bismarck has busied himself with the consideration of measures for the benefit of the working classes. Italy is prosperous and in alliance with Germany and Austria. Hungary has claimed more than her share of attention by riots in Vienna and the t-ial of Jews for the murder of a Christian girl. The Czar was crowned at Moscow in May, and Nihilism is less active. The people of the United States have been intensely interested in the movements of Irish fanatics. The prospects of the Democratic party are Btill favourable, and the Protectionists carried a Tariff Bill. Among the remarkable events, outside the region of politics, of the past twelve months, we have to record at home the success of the Fisheries Exhibition at South Kensington ; the transfer of the Law Courts from Westminster and Lincoln's Inn to the new buildings at Temple Bar ; the collapse of the Channel Tunnel Scheme and of the Manchester Ship Canal project; the celebration of Sir Moses Montefiore a entrance upon his hundredth sear; the successful introduction of the Parcels Post into this country, with the promise of cheapened telegrams and other postal improvements by Mr. Fawcett, and the ac- ceptance of a peerage by the Poet Laureate The Lord Chief Justice met with a very cordial reception in the United States, and among international affairs the celebration of the 400 th anniversary of Luther's birth should find a place. The destruction of Casamicciola, in the Island of Isehia, by an earth- quake was exceeded in horror by the stupendous upheaval of Krakatoa, on the coast of Java, the most formidable volcanic eruption recorded in modern times. The explosion and the tidal wave that followed it swept away, it was computed, at least 50,000 human beings, and transformed the geography of the region of the Sunda Straits. To this event some scientific authorities have referred the magnificent sunsets observed all over the world in November and December, but the theory has not been universally accepted. The obituary of 1883 includes among English public men who have passed away such names as the Dnke of Marlborough, beßt kDown as Viceroy of Ireland under Lord Beaconsfield; Lord Overstone, the ablest and most influential of English capitalists and the highest authority for many years on financial ques- tions ; Sir George Jessel, Master of the Rolls ; Mr. Law ( Lord Chancellor of Ireland, who had a large share in the authorship and conduct through Parliament of the Land Act ; Dr. Colenso, Bishop of Natal; three ex-judges of distinguished merit, Sir Samuel Martin, Sir Bichard Amphlett, and Sir Charles Hall ; and General Sir W. F. Williams, whose defence of Karß will live in history. Science has suffered in the deaths of Sir W. Siemens, and Professor Smith, the profound mathematician. English literature has suffered in the ! lobs of Mr. J. R. Green, the historian; and art in Richard Doyle. Others who have joined the majority are Mr. Holloway the philanthropist, Captain Mayne Reid, j Captain Webb, and John Brown. France has lost M- ! Gambetta, the Comte de Chambord. and Henri Martin tha historian ; in art, M. Guftave Dore : in society, the | Comta de Lagrange. Germany moarns for Herr j Wagner, for Flotow, and the veteran scholar Dindorf. Busiia has lost Piioce Gortsohakoff, and Ivan Turgenieff, the most powerful imaginative writer I Slavonic literature ever boasted. Italy, and the world* | bewail the less of the tenor Mario ; and Greece mourns ' one of her best leaders, M. Coumonndouros.
